On the simplest scale invariant Tree-Tensor-States
preserving the quantum symmetries of the antiferromagnetic XXZ chain

C√©cile Monthus Institut de Physique Th√©orique, Universit√© Paris Saclay, CNRS, CEA, 91191 Gif-sur-Yvette, France
Abstract

For the line of critical antiferromagnetic XXZ chains with coupling J>0ùêΩ0J>0 and anisotropy 0<Œî‚â§10Œî10<\Delta\leq 1, we describe how the block-spin renormalization procedure preserving the S‚ÄãUq‚Äã(2)ùëÜsubscriptùëàùëû2SU_{q}(2) symmetry introduced by Martin-Delgado and Sierra [Phys. Rev. Lett. 76, 1146 (1996)] can be reformulated as the translation-invariant scale-invariant Tree-Tensor-State of the smallest dimension that is compatible with the quantum symmetries of the model. The properties of this Tree-Tensor-State are studied in detail via the ground-state energy, the magnetizations and the staggered magnetizations, as well as the Shannon-Renyi entropies characterizing the multifractality of the components of the wave function.

I Introduction

Quantum information ideas [1] have profoundly changed the perspective on many condensed matter problems (see the book [2] and references therein). In particular, various real-space renormalization procedures have been reinterpreted from the point of view of Tensor Network States (see the reviews [3, 4, 5, 6, 7, 8, 9] and references therein) with the following output for the ground state of one-dimensional quantum spin chains : the Density-Matrix-RG introduced by S. White [10] corresponds to Matrix-Products-States that are well adapted to describe non-critical states displaying area-law entanglement, while the traditional block-spin renormalization for critical points corresponds to scale-invariant Tree-Tensor-States. In addition, this way of thinking has produced completely new types of renormalization procedures, like the multi-scale-entanglement-renormalization-ansatz (MERA) [11, 12] for critical models, where ‚Äôdisentanglers‚Äô between blocks are introduced besides the block-coarse-graining operators already present in Tree-Tensor-States (more details can be found in the reviews [5, 6, 7, 8]).

As stressed in the review [13], the ‚Äôold‚Äô block-spin renormalization procedures and the ‚Äônew‚Äô tensor-network approaches have remained different in their aims : the goal of block-spin renormalization is to produce some explicit tractable RG flow for the few parameters of the initial Hamiltonian, while the Tensor Network activity is more oriented towards the production of very powerful numerical algorithms, based on the variational optimization of the whole Tensor Network representing the ground state wave function, and where the numerical precision can be systematically improved by increasing the dimension of the elementary tensors. Nevertheless, it seems useful to establish some bridges between the two points of view, at least on specific examples. In the present paper, we thus consider the critical line of the XXZ antiferromagnetic chain, for which Martin-Delgado and Sierra have proposed a simple block-spin procedure that takes into account the S‚ÄãUq‚Äã(2)ùëÜsubscriptùëàùëû2SU_{q}(2) symmetry via the introduction of boundary fields in the intra-block Hamiltonian [14, 15, 16]. Here, we describe how the obtained solution can be reformulated as the simplest scale-invariant Tree-Tensor-State compatible with the quantum symmetries of the model, and analyze in detail its various properties.

The paper is organized as follows. Section II contains a reminder on the XXZ chain and the quantum group S‚ÄãUq‚Äã(2)ùëÜsubscriptùëàùëû2SU_{q}(2). In section III, we discuss the construction of scale-invariant Tree-Tensor-State compatible with the quantum symmetries of the model. In section IV, the scaling properties of local operators involving one spin or two spins are analyzed, in order to compute the ground-state energy, the magnetizations and the staggered magnetizations. The section V is then devoted to the Shannon-Renyi entropies that characterize the multifractality of the components of the wave function. Our conclusions are summarized in section VI.

An important technical point is that in all computations, qùëûq should be treated as a formal variable that is left unchanged by complex conjugation [20] so that the q-deformed ladder operators of Eq. 12 are the adjoint operators of each other [20]

Œ£i+=(Œ£i‚àí)‚Ä†superscriptsubscriptŒ£ùëñsuperscriptsuperscriptsubscriptŒ£ùëñ‚Ä†\displaystyle\Sigma_{i}^{+}=(\Sigma_{i}^{-})^{\dagger} (15)

where the boundary fields in Eq 7 are imaginary [20]

so that the Hamiltonian of Eq. 8 is actually not self-adjoint, even if its eigenvalues remain real [20]. In summary, all the intermediate calculations have to be performed with the formal variable qùëûq left unchanged by complex conjugation, even if at the end of the day, one wishes to apply the final results of the computations to the critical region with complex qùëûq (Eq. 16).

II.3 Supplementary symmetries

It is useful to introduce the following supplementary symmetries of the Hamiltonian H{J,q}subscriptùêªùêΩùëûH_{\{J,q\}} and the S‚ÄãUq‚Äã(2)ùëÜsubscriptùëàùëû2SU_{q}(2) generators Œ£¬±,Œ£zsuperscriptŒ£plus-or-minussuperscriptŒ£ùëß\Sigma^{\pm},\Sigma^{z} [20] :

(1) the Relabeling symmetry where the sites (1,2,..,N)(1,2,..,N) are relabeled in reverse order by (N,N‚àí1,..,1)(N,N-1,..,1) and where qùëûq is replaced by q‚àí1superscriptùëû1q^{-1} [20]

R‚â°{(1,2,..,N)‚Üí(N,N‚àí1,..,1);q‚Üíq‚àí1}\displaystyle R\equiv\{(1,2,..,N)\to(N,N-1,..,1);q\to q^{-1}\} (18)

satisfy R2=1superscriptùëÖ21R^{2}=1 and can be usedl to characterize the symmetry rj=1subscriptùëüùëó1r_{j}=1 or antisymmetry rj=‚àí1subscriptùëüùëó1r_{j}=-1 of multiplets

R‚Äã|j,m>=rj‚Äã|j,m>ùëÖketùëóùëösubscriptùëüùëóketùëóùëö\displaystyle R|j,m>=r_{j}|j,m> (19)

(2) the Flip Symmetry where all the zùëßz-components are flipped œÉiz‚Üí‚àíœÉiz‚Üísuperscriptsubscriptùúéùëñùëßsuperscriptsubscriptùúéùëñùëß\sigma_{i}^{z}\to-\sigma_{i}^{z} and where qùëûq is replaced by q‚àí1superscriptùëû1q^{-1} [20] relates the states of opposite magnetizations in a given multiplet (or the same state for the zero-magnetization state m=0ùëö0m=0)

F‚Äã|j,m>=œµj‚Äã|j,‚àím>ùêπketùëóùëösubscriptitalic-œµùëóketùëóùëö\displaystyle F|j,m>=\epsilon_{j}|j,-m> (20)

Let us now describe explicitly how all these symmetries allows to structure the Hilbert space for a small number of spins.

II.4 Example with b=2ùëè2b=2 sites

III.1 Coarse-graining with blocks of b=3ùëè3b=3 spins

To see how it works, it is now useful to consider the simplest examples of operators containing only a few spin operators :

(0) Zero-spin operator : the identity IœÉsubscriptùêºùúéI_{\sigma} is projected onto the identity IœÑsubscriptùêºùúèI_{\tau} as a consequence of Eq 29

ùíú‚Äã[IœÉ]=W‚ÄãIœÉ‚ÄãW‚Ä†=IœÑùíúdelimited-[]subscriptùêºùúéùëäsubscriptùêºùúésuperscriptùëä‚Ä†subscriptùêºùúè\displaystyle{\cal A}[I_{\sigma}]=WI_{\sigma}W^{\dagger}=I_{\tau} (36)

(1) One-spin operator œÉiŒ±superscriptsubscriptùúéùëñùõº\sigma_{i}^{\alpha} : the projection of a single spin operator involves only the corresponding renormalized spin operators œÑjŒ≤superscriptsubscriptùúèùëóùõΩ\tau_{j}^{\beta}.

(2) Two consecutive spin operators œÉiŒ±‚ÄãœÉi+1Œ±‚Ä≤superscriptsubscriptùúéùëñùõºsuperscriptsubscriptùúéùëñ1superscriptùõº‚Ä≤\sigma_{i}^{\alpha}\sigma_{i+1}^{\alpha^{\prime}} : here depending on the position of the pair with respect to the blocks, the projection will involve either a single renormalized spin œÑjsubscriptùúèùëó\tau_{j}, or two consecutive renormalized spins œÑjsubscriptùúèùëó\tau_{j} and œÑj+1subscriptùúèùëó1\tau_{j+1}.

(3) Three consecutive spin operators œÉiŒ±‚ÄãœÉi+1Œ±‚Ä≤‚ÄãœÉi+2Œ±‚Ä≤‚Ä≤superscriptsubscriptùúéùëñùõºsuperscriptsubscriptùúéùëñ1superscriptùõº‚Ä≤superscriptsubscriptùúéùëñ2superscriptùõº‚Ä≤‚Ä≤\sigma_{i}^{\alpha}\sigma_{i+1}^{\alpha^{\prime}}\sigma_{i+2}^{\alpha^{\prime\prime}} : here the projection can involve either a single renormalized spin œÑjsubscriptùúèùëó\tau_{j}, or two consecutive renormalized spins œÑjsubscriptùúèùëó\tau_{j} and œÑj+1subscriptùúèùëó1\tau_{j+1}, but cannot produce three consecutive renormalized spins operators.

III.3 Choice of the isometry wùë§w preserving the S‚ÄãUq‚Äã(2)ùëÜsubscriptùëàùëû2SU_{q}(2) symmetry

The choice of the isometry wùë§w is the point where the traditional block-spin renormalization approach and the Tensor-Network perspective differ.

In the traditional block-spin renormalization approach, the isometry wùë§w of Eq. 28 is chosen by requiring that the two kept states |œàj¬±>ketsuperscriptsubscriptùúìùëóplus-or-minus|\psi_{j}^{\pm}> are the ground-states of some ‚Äôintra-block Hamiltonian‚Äô involving only the three initial spins (œÉ3‚Äãj‚àí2,œÉ3‚Äãj‚àí1,œÉ3‚Äãj)subscriptùúé3ùëó2subscriptùúé3ùëó1subscriptùúé3ùëó(\sigma_{3j-2},\sigma_{3j-1},\sigma_{3j}). The ‚Äôcomputational advantage‚Äô is that the diagonalization of the three spins Hamiltonian usually gives simple explicit results for |œàj¬±>ketsuperscriptsubscriptùúìùëóplus-or-minus|\psi_{j}^{\pm}> as a function of the couplings of the Hamiltonian. The first ‚Äôtheoretical drawback‚Äô is that there is some arbitrariness in the decomposition of the Hamiltonian into ‚Äôintra-block‚Äô and ‚Äôextra-block‚Äô contributions that can lead to completely different outputs, so that the quality of the results will strongly depend on the ‚Äôcleverness‚Äô of the choice of the intra-block Hamiltonian. The second ‚Äôtheoretical drawback‚Äô is that the choice of the ground states of the ‚Äôintra-block Hamiltonian‚Äô does not take at all into account the ‚Äôenvironment‚Äô of the neighboring blocks.

In the Tree-Tensor-Network perspective (see the reviews [3, 4, 5, 6, 7, 8, 9] and references therein), one represents instead the whole ground-state wavefunction |œàNG‚ÄãS>ketsubscriptsuperscriptùúìùê∫ùëÜùëÅ|\psi^{GS}_{N}> as a tree-tensor-state involving isometries, and the choice of the isometries is based on the minimization of the total energy

ENG‚ÄãS=<œàNG‚ÄãS|H|œàNG‚ÄãS>subscriptsuperscriptùê∏ùê∫ùëÜùëÅquantum-operator-productsubscriptsuperscriptùúìùê∫ùëÜùëÅùêªsubscriptsuperscriptùúìùê∫ùëÜùëÅ\displaystyle E^{GS}_{N}=<\psi^{GS}_{N}|H|\psi^{GS}_{N}> (37)

The ‚Äôcomputational drawback‚Äô is that this global minimization can usually only be done numerically. However, the number of parameters can be drastically reduced if one takes into account all the symmetries of the model (see the review [9] and references therein). In the following, we describe how the symmetries of the XXZ chain allows to constraint sufficiently the possible isometries of the smallest dimension in order to obtain an analytical solution.

(i) Translation-invariance : for models that are translation-invariant in the bulk, the isometries wjsubscriptùë§ùëów_{j} of Eq. 28 are chosen to be the same in each block j=1,..,N3j=1,..,\frac{N}{3}. It is important to stress however that the decomposition into blocks breaks nevertheless the equivalence between the three spins inside each block : this issue will be further discussed below.

(ii) Scale-invariance : for translation-invariant critical models, the coarse-graining procedure can be iterated with the same isometry wùë§w for the (ln‚Å°Nln‚Å°3)ùëÅ3(\frac{\ln N}{\ln 3}) layers representing the successive renormalization steps : the initial layer t=0ùë°0t=0 contains the NùëÅN initial spins œÉisubscriptùúéùëñ\sigma_{i}, the first layer t=1ùë°1t=1 contains N3ùëÅ3\frac{N}{3} renormalized spins œÑjsubscriptùúèùëó\tau_{j}, the layer t=2ùë°2t=2 contains N9ùëÅ9\frac{N}{9} second renormalized spins‚Ä¶ up to the top layer t=ln‚Å°Nln‚Å°3ùë°ùëÅ3t=\frac{\ln N}{\ln 3} containing a single t-renormalized spin representing the two degenerate ground-states of the whole chain. In summary at this stage, the ground-state wavefunction |œàNG‚ÄãS>ketsubscriptsuperscriptùúìùê∫ùëÜùëÅ|\psi^{GS}_{N}> is written as a translation-invariant scale-invariant tree-tensor state involving the same isometry wùë§w everywhere in all layers.

(iii) S‚ÄãUq‚Äã(2)ùëÜsubscriptùëàùëû2SU_{q}(2) symmetry : the presence of symmetries in tensor networks states is discussed in detail in the series of papers [21, 22, 23, 24, 25], and the present S‚ÄãUq‚Äã(2)ùëÜsubscriptùëàùëû2SU_{q}(2) symmetry can be considered as a deformation of the S‚ÄãU‚Äã(2)ùëÜùëà2SU(2) symmetry analyzed in [23]. However, since we focus here only on tree-tensor state involving the isometry wùë§w with the smallest possible dimension (Eq. 28), we do not need the full formalism described in [23] for general tensors in the presence of the SU(2) symmetry, but we can use the language of the initial spins œÉùúé\sigma and the renormalized spins œÑùúè\tau to simplify the analysis. The idea is to introduce the S‚ÄãUq‚Äã(2)ùëÜsubscriptùëàùëû2SU_{q}(2) generators for the renormalized spins œÑùúè\tau similar to Eq. 12

Tzsuperscriptùëáùëß\displaystyle T^{z} =‚àëj=1N3œÑjzabsentsuperscriptsubscriptùëó1ùëÅ3superscriptsubscriptùúèùëóùëß\displaystyle=\sum_{j=1}^{\frac{N}{3}}\tau_{j}^{z}
T¬±superscriptùëáplus-or-minus\displaystyle T^{\pm} =‚àëj=1N3Tj¬±absentsuperscriptsubscriptùëó1ùëÅ3superscriptsubscriptùëáùëóplus-or-minus\displaystyle=\sum_{j=1}^{\frac{N}{3}}T_{j}^{\pm}

and to require that the generators of the S‚ÄãUq‚Äã(2)ùëÜsubscriptùëàùëû2SU_{q}(2) symmetry are preserved by the coarse-graining procedure as described by the ascending super-operator ùíúùíú{\cal A} introduced in Eq. 34

Since the S‚ÄãUq‚Äã(2)ùëÜsubscriptùëàùëû2SU_{q}(2) representations for b=2ùëè2b=2 spins (section II.4) only contains a triplet j=1ùëó1j=1 and a singlet j=0ùëó0j=0, one obtains that the coarse-graining with blocks of b=2ùëè2b=2 sites are not compatible with the S‚ÄãUq‚Äã(2)ùëÜsubscriptùëàùëû2SU_{q}(2) symmetry. Since the S‚ÄãUq‚Äã(2)ùëÜsubscriptùëàùëû2SU_{q}(2) representations for b=3ùëè3b=3 spins (section II.5) contains a quadruplet j=3/2ùëó32j=3/2 and two doublets j=1/2ùëó12j=1/2 that have different quantum number r=¬±1ùëüplus-or-minus1r=\pm 1 for the relabeling symmetry, one concludes that there are only two possible isometries that are compatible with the S‚ÄãUq‚Äã(2)ùëÜsubscriptùëàùëû2SU_{q}(2) and the relabeling symmetry :

(a) the isometry wasubscriptùë§ùëéw_{a} based on the choice |œà¬±>=|a¬±>ketsuperscriptùúìplus-or-minusketsuperscriptùëéplus-or-minus|\psi^{\pm}>=|a^{\pm}> of Eq 26

wasubscriptùë§ùëé\displaystyle w_{a} =|œÑz=+1>‚Äã<a+|+|œÑz=‚àí1>‚Äã<a‚àí|absentketsuperscriptùúèùëß1brasuperscriptùëéketsuperscriptùúèùëß1brasuperscriptùëé\displaystyle=|\tau^{z}=+1><a^{+}|+|\tau^{z}=-1><a^{-}| (42)

(b) the isometry wbsubscriptùë§ùëèw_{b} based on the choice |œà¬±>=|b¬±>ketsuperscriptùúìplus-or-minusketsuperscriptùëèplus-or-minus|\psi^{\pm}>=|b^{\pm}> of Eq 27

So one needs to compare the ground state energies (Eq. 37) for the two tree-tensor-states |œàaG‚ÄãS>ketsubscriptsuperscriptùúìùê∫ùëÜùëé|\psi^{GS}_{a}> and |œàbG‚ÄãS>ketsubscriptsuperscriptùúìùê∫ùëÜùëè|\psi^{GS}_{b}> based on the isometries wasubscriptùë§ùëéw_{a} and wbsubscriptùë§ùëèw_{b} respectively. Physically, one expects that this coarse-graining based on S‚ÄãUq‚Äã(2)ùëÜsubscriptùëàùëû2SU_{q}(2) representations with j=1/2ùëó12j=1/2 up to the whole ground state has a meaning only in the antiferromagnetic critical region

0<Œî‚â§10Œî1\displaystyle 0<\Delta\leq 1 (44)

while the ferromagnetic critical region ‚àí1<Œî<01Œî0-1<\Delta<0 would require to consider higher representations and thus isometries of higher dimensions.

IV Magnetic and energetic properties of the tree-tensor-state

In this section, we describe the magnetic and energetic properties of the tree-tensor-state based on the isometry wasubscriptùë§ùëéw_{a} of Eq. 42, while the comparison with the isometry wbsubscriptùë§ùëèw_{b} of Eq. 43 is postponed to section IV.5.

IV.1 Renormalization rules for spin operators inside a given block

The action of the ascending super-operator ùíúùíú{\cal A} on any observable localized on a single block can be obtained by Eq. 35. Since all block are the same, let us simplify the notations and write the renormalization rules for the three initial spins (œÉ1,œÉ2,œÉ3)subscriptùúé1subscriptùúé2subscriptùúé3(\sigma_{1},\sigma_{2},\sigma_{3}) in terms of the corresponding renormalized spin œÑùúè\tau of the block.

Inside a given block of three sites, the renormalization rules are different for the three spins (œÉ1,œÉ2,œÉ3)subscriptùúé1subscriptùúé2subscriptùúé3(\sigma_{1},\sigma_{2},\sigma_{3}). The two boundary spins operators are renormalized according to

ùíú‚Äã(œÉ1¬±)ùíúsubscriptsuperscriptùúéplus-or-minus1\displaystyle{\cal A}(\sigma^{\pm}_{1}) =Œ∂‚ÄãœÑ¬±absentùúÅsuperscriptùúèplus-or-minus\displaystyle=\zeta\tau^{\pm}
ùíú‚Äã(œÉ3¬±)ùíúsubscriptsuperscriptùúéplus-or-minus3\displaystyle{\cal A}(\sigma^{\pm}_{3}) =Œ∂‚ÄãœÑ¬±absentùúÅsuperscriptùúèplus-or-minus\displaystyle=\zeta\tau^{\pm} (45)

and

ùíú‚Äã(œÉ3z)ùíúsubscriptsuperscriptùúéùëß3\displaystyle{\cal A}(\sigma^{z}_{3}) =Œ∂‚ÄãœÑz+œâabsentùúÅsuperscriptùúèùëßùúî\displaystyle=\zeta\tau^{z}+\omega (46)

IV.2 Scaling dimensions of the magnetization and the staggered magnetization

For Œ±=x,y,zùõºùë•ùë¶ùëß\alpha=x,y,z, we are interested into the scaling of the magnetizations for the full chain

‚Ñ≥NŒ±=‚àëj=1NœÉjŒ±superscriptsubscript‚Ñ≥ùëÅùõºsuperscriptsubscriptùëó1ùëÅsuperscriptsubscriptùúéùëóùõº\displaystyle{\cal M}_{N}^{\alpha}=\sum_{j=1}^{N}\sigma_{j}^{\alpha} (53)

ùíú‚Äã(œÉ3‚Äãj‚àí2z+œÉ3‚Äãj‚àí1z+œÉ3‚Äãjz)ùíúsuperscriptsubscriptùúé3ùëó2ùëßsuperscriptsubscriptùúé3ùëó1ùëßsuperscriptsubscriptùúé3ùëóùëß\displaystyle{\cal A}(\sigma_{3j-2}^{z}+\sigma_{3j-1}^{z}+\sigma_{3j}^{z}) =(Œ∂+Œº2+Œ∂)‚ÄãœÑjz=œÑjzabsentùúÅsubscriptùúá2ùúÅsuperscriptsubscriptùúèùëóùëßsuperscriptsubscriptùúèùëóùëß\displaystyle=(\zeta+\mu_{2}+\zeta)\tau_{j}^{z}=\tau_{j}^{z}
ùíú‚Äã(œÉ3‚Äãj‚àí2¬±+œÉ3‚Äãj‚àí1¬±+œÉ3‚Äãj¬±)ùíúsuperscriptsubscriptùúé3ùëó2plus-or-minussuperscriptsubscriptùúé3ùëó1plus-or-minussuperscriptsubscriptùúé3ùëóplus-or-minus\displaystyle{\cal A}(\sigma_{3j-2}^{\pm}+\sigma_{3j-1}^{\pm}+\sigma_{3j}^{\pm}) =(Œ∂+Œ∂2+Œ∂)‚ÄãœÑj¬±=2+Œî1+2‚ÄãŒî‚ÄãœÑj¬±absentùúÅsubscriptùúÅ2ùúÅsuperscriptsubscriptùúèùëóplus-or-minus2Œî12Œîsuperscriptsubscriptùúèùëóplus-or-minus\displaystyle=(\zeta+\zeta_{2}+\zeta)\tau_{j}^{\pm}=\frac{2+\Delta}{1+2\Delta}\tau_{j}^{\pm} (55)

ùíú‚Äã(‚Ñã3‚Äãj‚àí2,3‚Äãj‚àí1+‚Ñã3‚Äãj‚àí1,3‚Äãj)ùíúsubscript‚Ñã3ùëó23ùëó1subscript‚Ñã3ùëó13ùëó\displaystyle{\cal A}({\cal H}_{3j-2,3j-1}+{\cal H}_{3j-1,3j}) =ei‚Äãnabsentsubscriptùëíùëñùëõ\displaystyle=e_{in} (62)

IV.5 Comparison with the tree-tensor-state based on the isometry wbsubscriptùë§ùëèw_{b}

The properties of the tree-tensor-state based on the isometry wbsubscriptùë§ùëèw_{b} of Eq. 43 can be computed similarly. However in the region (J>0,Œî>0)formulae-sequenceùêΩ0Œî0(J>0,\Delta>0) that we consider, one obtains that wasubscriptùë§ùëéw_{a} is the good solution, while wbsubscriptùë§ùëèw_{b} would be the good solution in the region J<0ùêΩ0J<0 and Œî<0Œî0\Delta<0 in relation with the symmetry J‚Üí‚àíJ‚ÜíùêΩùêΩJ\to-J and Œî‚Üí‚àíŒî‚ÜíŒîŒî\Delta\to-\Delta of Eq. 5.

It is now interesting to return to the discussion of section III.3 on the choice of the isometry wùë§w :

(i) within the standard Block-spin Renormalization perspective, the choice between wasubscriptùë§ùëéw_{a} and wbsubscriptùë§ùëèw_{b} is based on the comparison of the ground-state energy EG‚ÄãS‚Äã(N)superscriptùê∏ùê∫ùëÜùëÅE^{GS(N)} for blocks of size N=3ùëÅ3N=3 [14], that read

V Shannon-R√©nyi entropies of the tree-tensor state

The groundstate wavefunction of manybody quantum systems have been found to be generically multifractal, with many studies concerning the Shannon-R√©nyi entropies in pure quantum spin models [28, 29, 30, 31, 33, 32, 34, 35, 36, 37, 38, 39, 40, 41], or focusing on the weight of the dominant configuration, for instance the N√©el state for the present XXZ model [26, 27, 42]. It is thus interesting in this section to analyze the multifractal properties of the tree-tensor-state.

V.2 Renormalization rule for the Renyi entropies

Block-spin renormalization has already been used to analyze the Renyi entropies of the pure and random quantum Ising chains [41]. Here we apply the same strategy to the Tree-Tensor-State for the XXZ chain.

The weight of a given configuration (S1,..,SN)(S_{1},..,S_{N}) of the initial spins in the (œÉz)superscriptùúéùëß(\sigma^{z}) basis is directly related to the weight of the corresponding renormalized configuration (œÑ1,‚Ä¶,œÑN3)subscriptùúè1‚Ä¶subscriptùúèùëÅ3(\tau_{1},...,\tau_{\frac{N}{3}}) in the œÑzsuperscriptùúèùëß\tau^{z} basis with the fixed values œÑj=‚àíS3‚Äãj‚àí2‚ÄãS3‚Äãj‚àí1‚ÄãS3‚ÄãjsubscriptùúèùëósubscriptùëÜ3ùëó2subscriptùëÜ3ùëó1subscriptùëÜ3ùëó\tau_{j}=-S_{3j-2}S_{3j-1}S_{3j}

|œà‚Äã(S1,S2,‚Ä¶,SN)|2=|œàR‚Äã(œÑ1,‚Ä¶,œÑN3)|2‚Äã‚àèj=1N3[Œ¥œÑj=‚àíS3‚Äãj‚àí2‚ÄãS3‚Äãj‚àí1‚ÄãS3‚Äãj‚Äã|<S3‚Äãj‚àí2‚ÄãS3‚Äãj‚àí1‚ÄãS3‚Äãj|‚ÄãaœÑj|2]superscriptùúìsubscriptùëÜ1subscriptùëÜ2‚Ä¶subscriptùëÜùëÅ2superscriptsuperscriptùúìùëÖsubscriptùúè1‚Ä¶subscriptùúèùëÅ32superscriptsubscriptproductùëó1ùëÅ3delimited-[]subscriptùõøsubscriptùúèùëósubscriptùëÜ3ùëó2subscriptùëÜ3ùëó1subscriptùëÜ3ùëósuperscriptbrasubscriptùëÜ3ùëó2subscriptùëÜ3ùëó1subscriptùëÜ3ùëósuperscriptùëésubscriptùúèùëó2\displaystyle|\psi(S_{1},S_{2},...,S_{N})|^{2}=|\psi^{R}(\tau_{1},...,\tau_{\frac{N}{3}})|^{2}\prod_{j=1}^{\frac{N}{3}}\left[\delta_{\tau_{j}=-S_{3j-2}S_{3j-1}S_{3j}}|<S_{3j-2}S_{3j-1}S_{3j}|a^{\tau_{j}}|^{2}\right] (81)

D‚àû‚Äã(Œî)=12‚Äãln‚Å°2‚Äãln‚Å°(1+2‚ÄãŒî1+Œî)subscriptùê∑Œî12212Œî1Œî\displaystyle D_{\infty}(\Delta)=\frac{1}{2\ln 2}\ln\left(\frac{1+2\Delta}{1+\Delta}\right) (89)

characterizes the scaling of the maximal coefficient œàm‚Äãa‚Äãxsubscriptùúìùëöùëéùë•\psi_{max} (Eq. 80), which occurs for the N√©el state in the present antiferromagnetic XXZ chain

For instance for the isotropic case Œî=1Œî1\Delta=1 and the anisotropic case Œî=1/2Œî12\Delta=1/2, Eq. 89 corresponds to the values

D‚àû‚Äã(Œî=1)subscriptùê∑Œî1\displaystyle D_{\infty}(\Delta=1) =ln‚Å°32‚Äãln‚Å°2‚àí12‚âÉ0.2925‚Äã‚Ä¶absent32212similar-to-or-equals0.2925‚Ä¶\displaystyle=\frac{\ln 3}{2\ln 2}-\frac{1}{2}\simeq 0.2925...
D‚àû‚Äã(Œî=1/2)subscriptùê∑Œî12\displaystyle D_{\infty}(\Delta=1/2) =1‚àíln‚Å°32‚Äãln‚Å°2‚âÉ0.2075‚Äã‚Ä¶absent1322similar-to-or-equals0.2075‚Ä¶\displaystyle=1-\frac{\ln 3}{2\ln 2}\simeq 0.2075... (91)

V.4 Correlation dimension Dp=2subscriptùê∑ùëù2D_{p=2}

For p=2ùëù2p=2, Eq. 86 turns out to reduce to the simple fraction 1/2121/2 independently of ŒîŒî\Delta

Dp=2‚Äã(Œî)=12subscriptùê∑ùëù2Œî12\displaystyle D_{p=2}(\Delta)=\frac{1}{2} (92)

that translates into the sum rule

Yp=2(N)‚â°‚àëS1=¬±1‚àëS2=¬±1..‚àëSN=¬±1|œà(S1,S2,‚Ä¶,SN)|4‚àùN‚Üí+‚àû2‚àíN\displaystyle Y_{p=2}(N)\equiv\sum_{S_{1}=\pm 1}\sum_{S_{2}=\pm 1}..\sum_{S_{N}=\pm 1}|\psi(S_{1},S_{2},...,S_{N})|^{4}\mathop{\propto}_{N\to+\infty}\sqrt{2^{-N}} (93)

It is not clear to us whether this property has a simple physical explanation.

V.5 Information dimension Dp=1subscriptùê∑ùëù1D_{p=1}

For p=1ùëù1p=1, the information dimension

D1‚Äã(Œî)=(1+2‚ÄãŒî)‚Äãln‚Å°(1+2‚ÄãŒî)‚àí(1+Œî)‚Äãln‚Å°(1+Œî)+Œî‚Äãln‚Å°2+1‚àíŒî2‚Äãarccos‚Å°(Œî)2‚Äãln‚Å°2‚Äã(1+2‚ÄãŒî)subscriptùê∑1Œî12Œî12Œî1Œî1ŒîŒî21superscriptŒî2Œî2212Œî\displaystyle D_{1}(\Delta)=\frac{(1+2\Delta)\ln(1+2\Delta)-(1+\Delta)\ln(1+\Delta)+\Delta\ln 2+\sqrt{1-\Delta^{2}}\arccos(\Delta)}{2\ln 2(1+2\Delta)} (94)

gives the following values for the isotropic case Œî=1Œî1\Delta=1 and the anisotropic case Œî=1/2Œî12\Delta=1/2

D1‚Äã(Œî=1)subscriptùê∑1Œî1\displaystyle D_{1}(\Delta=1) =ln‚Å°32‚Äãln‚Å°2‚àí16‚âÉ0.6258‚Äã‚Ä¶absent32216similar-to-or-equals0.6258‚Ä¶\displaystyle=\frac{\ln 3}{2\ln 2}-\frac{1}{6}\simeq 0.6258...
D1‚Äã(Œî=1/2)subscriptùê∑1Œî12\displaystyle D_{1}(\Delta=1/2) =1‚àí3‚Äãln‚Å°3‚àíœÄ38‚Äãln‚Å°2‚âÉ0.7327‚Äã‚Ä¶absent133ùúã382similar-to-or-equals0.7327‚Ä¶\displaystyle=1-\frac{3\ln 3-\frac{\pi}{\sqrt{3}}}{8\ln 2}\simeq 0.7327... (95)

V.6 Dimension Dp=1/2subscriptùê∑ùëù12D_{p=1/2}

For the value p=1/2ùëù12p=1/2, the value of Eq. 86

Dp=1/2‚Äã(Œî)=1‚àí12‚Äãln‚Å°2‚Äãln‚Å°(1+2‚ÄãŒî1+Œî)subscriptùê∑ùëù12Œî112212Œî1Œî\displaystyle D_{p=1/2}(\Delta)=1-\frac{1}{2\ln 2}\ln\left(\frac{1+2\Delta}{1+\Delta}\right) (96)

is found to satisfy the simple relation with D‚àû‚Äã(Œî)subscriptùê∑ŒîD_{\infty}(\Delta) of Eq. 89

Dp=1/2‚Äã(Œî)=1‚àíD‚àû‚Äã(Œî)subscriptùê∑ùëù12Œî1subscriptùê∑Œî\displaystyle D_{p=1/2}(\Delta)=1-D_{\infty}(\Delta) (97)

This relation is indeed expected for the isotropic model Œî=1Œî1\Delta=1 (see the review [37]) as a consequence of the expansion of the maximal configuration in the œÉzsuperscriptùúéùëß\sigma^{z} basis into the œÉxsuperscriptùúéùë•\sigma^{x} basis (or vice versa) leading to the following relation between Renyi entropies in the two different basis [37]

Sp=‚àûz‚Äã(Œî)=N‚Äãln‚Å°2‚àíSp=1/2x‚Äã(Œî)subscriptsuperscriptùëÜùëßùëùŒîùëÅ2subscriptsuperscriptùëÜùë•ùëù12Œî\displaystyle S^{z}_{p=\infty}(\Delta)=N\ln 2-S^{x}_{p=1/2}(\Delta)
Sp=‚àûx‚Äã(Œî)=N‚Äãln‚Å°2‚àíSp=1/2z‚Äã(Œî)subscriptsuperscriptùëÜùë•ùëùŒîùëÅ2subscriptsuperscriptùëÜùëßùëù12Œî\displaystyle S^{x}_{p=\infty}(\Delta)=N\ln 2-S^{z}_{p=1/2}(\Delta) (98)

and then the S‚ÄãU‚Äã(2)ùëÜùëà2SU(2) symmetry for the isotropic case Œî=1Œî1\Delta=1 yields that the Renyi entropies should be the same in the two basis Spx‚Äã(Œî=1)=Spz‚Äã(Œî=1)subscriptsuperscriptùëÜùë•ùëùŒî1subscriptsuperscriptùëÜùëßùëùŒî1S^{x}_{p}(\Delta=1)=S^{z}_{p}(\Delta=1) leading to Eq. 97 for Œî=1Œî1\Delta=1. For Œî‚â†1Œî1\Delta\neq 1, Eq. 97 can be explained for the Tree-Tensor-State as discussed below in section V.7.

For the isotropic case Œî=1Œî1\Delta=1 and the anisotropic case Œî=1/2Œî12\Delta=1/2, Eq. 96 corresponds to the values

Dp=1/2‚Äã(Œî=1)subscriptùê∑ùëù12Œî1\displaystyle D_{p=1/2}(\Delta=1) =32‚àíln‚Å°32‚Äãln‚Å°2‚âÉ0.7075‚Äã‚Ä¶absent32322similar-to-or-equals0.7075‚Ä¶\displaystyle=\frac{3}{2}-\frac{\ln 3}{2\ln 2}\simeq 0.7075...
Dp=1/2‚Äã(Œî=1/2)subscriptùê∑ùëù12Œî12\displaystyle D_{p=1/2}(\Delta=1/2) =ln‚Å°32‚Äãln‚Å°2‚âÉ0.7925‚Äã‚Ä¶absent322similar-to-or-equals0.7925‚Ä¶\displaystyle=\frac{\ln 3}{2\ln 2}\simeq 0.7925... (99)

This last value turns out to coincide with the exact value Dp=1/2‚Äã(Œî=1/2)subscriptùê∑ùëù12Œî12D_{p=1/2}(\Delta=1/2) computed for odd chains with periodic boundary conditions [26, 32, 34]. So despite the fact that the Tree-Tensor-State cannot describe the generalized dimensions in the region of small pùëùp near p=0ùëù0p=0 (see the discussion before Eq. 88), we see on this specific example Œî=1/2Œî12\Delta=1/2 that the Tree-Tensor-State is able to reproduce the correct dimension for the not-so-big value p=12ùëù12p=\frac{1}{2}.

V.7 Properties of the Tree-Tensor-State in the œÉxsuperscriptùúéùë•\sigma^{x} basis

For the isotropic case Œî=1=qŒî1ùëû\Delta=1=q, these states are similar to the expressions in the zùëßz-basis with only three components of the corresponding magnetization (Eq. 26), while for the anisotropic cases Œî‚â†1Œî1\Delta\neq 1, they are clearly different. As a consequence the Renyi entropies Spz‚Äã(Œî)subscriptsuperscriptùëÜùëßùëùŒîS^{z}_{p}(\Delta) and Spx‚Äã(Œî)subscriptsuperscriptùëÜùë•ùëùŒîS^{x}_{p}(\Delta) in the two basis are not expected to be the same for the anisotropic cases Œî‚â†1Œî1\Delta\neq 1 and generic index pùëùp. However in the limit p‚Üí+‚àû‚Üíùëùp\to+\infty, where only the weight of the maximal component œàm‚Äãa‚Äãxsubscriptùúìùëöùëéùë•\psi_{max} corresponding to the N√©el state in the two basis remains (Eq. 90), some simplification occurs in the œÉxsuperscriptùúéùë•\sigma^{x} basis : the N√©el state |+‚àí+>x|+-+>_{x} for the block only occurs in the renormalized state |œÑx=+1>xsubscriptketsuperscriptùúèùë•1ùë•|\tau^{x}=+1>_{x}, while the opposite N√©el state |‚àí+‚àí>x|-+->_{x} for the block only occurs in the renormalized state |œÑx=‚àí1>xsubscriptketsuperscriptùúèùë•1ùë•|\tau^{x}=-1>_{x}, and both weights are equal to the corresponding weight in the zùëßz-basis (Eq 26)

|x<+‚àí+|œÑx=+1>x|2=|x<‚àí+‚àí|œÑx=‚àí1>x|2=1+Œî1+2‚ÄãŒî=|z<+‚àí+|œÑz=+1>x|2\displaystyle|_{x}<+-+|\tau^{x}=+1>_{x}|^{2}=|_{x}<-+-|\tau^{x}=-1>_{x}|^{2}=\frac{1+\Delta}{1+2\Delta}=|_{z}<+-+|\tau^{z}=+1>_{x}|^{2} (102)

These properties lead to the equality of the Renyi entropies Spz‚Äã(Œî)subscriptsuperscriptùëÜùëßùëùŒîS^{z}_{p}(\Delta) and Spx‚Äã(Œî)subscriptsuperscriptùëÜùë•ùëùŒîS^{x}_{p}(\Delta) for p‚Üí+‚àû‚Üíùëùp\to+\infty

Sp=‚àûz‚Äã(Œî)=Sp=‚àûx‚Äã(Œî)subscriptsuperscriptùëÜùëßùëùŒîsubscriptsuperscriptùëÜùë•ùëùŒî\displaystyle S^{z}_{p=\infty}(\Delta)=S^{x}_{p=\infty}(\Delta) (103)

and explain the simple relation found in Eq. 97 for the Tree-Tensor-State.

VI Conclusions

For the line of critical antiferromagnetic XXZ chains with coupling J>0ùêΩ0J>0 and anisotropy 0<Œî‚â§10Œî10<\Delta\leq 1, we have obtained that the translation-invariant scale-invariant Tree-Tensor-State of the smallest dimension compatible with the quantum symmetries of the model corresponds to the block-spin renormalization procedure introduced previously by Martin-Delgado and Sierra via the introduction of boundary fields in the intra-block Hamiltonian to make it S‚ÄãUq‚Äã(2)ùëÜsubscriptùëàùëû2SU_{q}(2) invariant [14, 15, 16]. Even if the final output is the same, we have explained the differences in reasoning between the two points of view : in the block-spin renormalization approach, the solution is based on the lowest eigenstate EaG‚ÄãS‚Äã(N=3)subscriptsuperscriptùê∏ùê∫ùëÜùëÅ3ùëéE^{GS(N=3)}_{a} for the block of N=3ùëÅ3N=3 spins (Eq. 74), while in the Tree-Tensor approach, the chosen solution is based on the best ground-state-energy per site e0subscriptùëí0e_{0} in the thermodynamic limit N‚Üí+‚àû‚ÜíùëÅN\to+\infty, after the resummation of the contributions of all the renormalization scales (Eqs 70 and 71). As a consequence, the two criteria could turn out to be different in other models. In the future, it would be thus interesting to see for other critical quantum spin chains whether the Tree-Tensor approach agrees also with some previous choices of block-spin renormalization or produces new solutions.

In the second part of the paper, we have described the energetic and magnetic properties of the Tree-Tensor-State, as well as the as the multifractality of the components of the wave function. Despite its simplicity, the Tree-Tensor-State turns out to be able to reproduce some exact results for the anisotropic case Œî=1/2Œî12\Delta=1/2, like the ground-state energy (Eq. 73) or the multifractal dimension Dp=1/2subscriptùê∑ùëù12D_{p=1/2} of Eq. 99. Further work is needed to understand whether ‚Äôdisentanglers‚Äô between blocks preserving the S‚ÄãUq‚Äã(2)ùëÜsubscriptùëàùëû2SU_{q}(2) symmetry can be introduced besides the block-coarse-graining in order to produce some simple analytical MERA for the XXZ chain.
